Notes:

Print Drawer2 twice

These are models for plastic inserts to work with Banebot combat robot wheels. These can substitute for the Banebot aluminum hex shaft mount. They are compatible with the existing retaining rings and set screws from the hex mount kit.

They work with .5" retaining rings (like McMaster 97633A200) and 6-32 short setscrews (like McMaster 92158A158).

It is recommended to print with 100% or very high infill. Slow printing is recommended to ensure the teeth details are maintained.

30 teeth model versions are compatible with .080" pitch timing belts (such as McMaster 7887K23). These are perfect for easily making 4 wheel drive systems from two motors!

For the setscrew, you will need to tap the side hole with a 6-32 tap.

author: pmarreck

title: Pocket-Tactics: Core Set 7 (Fourth Edition)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
CORE SET 7: Men of Midgard against Vikings of the Far Shore

Welcome to the Fourth Edition of Pocket-Tactics, the modular, 3d-printable strategy board game that goes wherever you do!

This new edition represents years of streamlining, and we're excited to be ready to present this to you. Stay tuned for more sets and pieces, as well as updated rules for all of the previous edition's pieces.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

-------------------------------------------------RULES-------------------------------------------------------
For a standard core set, you'll want to print the following:
Midgard Spearman x1, Midgard Swordsman x1, Midgard Archer x1, Faithful Servant x1, Noble Lady x1, Noble Hero x1, Rune Singer x1, Enslaved Prisoner x1, Viking Bondi x1, Viking Reaver x1, Viking Archer x1, Berserker x1, Viking Champion x1, Viking Warlord x1, Ice tiles x3, Plains tiles x4, Water tiles x5, Longship Fleet x1, Ring Castle x1, Village x1

In addition, each player will need six dice (three red, and three blue).

Inverted-color images of the rules cards are available here, here. and here if you want something a little less ink-intensive.

SETTING UP

To begin, each player builds a force by selecting a number of units that total 50 points or less. For a larger game, you and your opponent could agree on a higher point total.

Next, each player chooses 6 tiles and all of the tiles are dropped into a bag and shuffled. Then, players agree (randomly, if you choose) on a “central feature” tile and then each choose a feature for themselves. (features are the 3-dimensional tiles such as Forest, Highlands, Villages, et cetera). Draw a single tile from the bag and place the central feature into that tile. Rolling off to see who goes first, players take turns drawing tiles from the bag and placing them adjacent to one another in whatever configuration they wish. Once all of the tiles have been placed, each player (in turn order decided by the roll-off) places their chosen feature so that it is both as many tiles away from the center and from one another as possible.

Once the map has been generated, players place up to three units of their choice (as many as they can fit) either in or adjacent to their chosen feature using the rolled-off turn order. You may only ever have a single unit occupy a tile or feature. Once this is finished, game play begins starting with the last player to place their units.

PLAYING THE GAME

Each turn, a player may either move one of their units, use one of their units to assault an enemy unit, or deploy a new unit onto the map.

MOVING: When activating a unit to move, they may do so into any unoccupied tile adjacent to them. If an allied unit is in an adjacent tile, the moving unit may “hop” over that unit to get to an open tile adjacent to their ally. A unit may only hop a single ally per move. Some features (Forests, Highlands, Villages, et cetera) have special movement considerations that will be listed on their rules card. Spaces that do not contain a tile may not be moved into.

SWIFT UNITS: Units with this symbol on their rules card may perform a number of bonus moves equal to the numeric value listed to the side when they are activated to move.

FLYING UNITS: Units with this symbol on their rules card may perform a number of bonus moves equal to the numeric value listed to the side when they are activated to move and may hop over enemy units as though they were allies when doing so.

ASSAULTS: When activating a unit to assault an adjacent enemy, each player tests their units Offense (OFF) by rolling their red dice and defense (DEF) by rolling their blue dice. A unit will have between zero and three of each kind of dice as shown on their rules cards. The assault occurs in three phases:

Roll Phase- All dice are rolled simultaneously.

Bump Phase- Some units have “bumps,” a numeric value with a + listed under either their OFF or DEF dice. Starting with the player initiating the assault, each player may take turns using a single bump. Each bump may adjust a single die result (either OFF or DEF) up by its value (though a single die may not go higher than 6). Some units may have multiple bump values listed under their dice or granted by special abilities or terrain effects.

Re-Roll Phase- Starting with the player initiating the assault, each player takes turns using any re-rolls they are afforded, either by special abilities or terrain/unit placement. Each re-roll allows the player to re-roll one of their die results (OFF or DEF). A unit that has adjacent allies is benefiting from “support” and gains one re-roll per ally. A unit also gains a single re-roll when occupying their “favored terrain” (a terrain tile or feature that is shown on their rules card).

Tally Phase- Each player checks their OFF results and checks them against the opponent's DEF results. Starting with the highest OFF die, compare it to the highest enemy DEF die. If the results are a tie, move on to the next highest. If a single OFF die can't be matched or beat by value from the enemy's DEF, that enemy is “defeated” and is removed from the map and placed in the victorious player's captures (a space to the side of the map on that player's side). If the OFF cannot beat the enemy DEF values, that unit is safe. Note that, because all dice are rolled at once, it is possible for both units to defeat one another simultaneously.

RANGED ATTACKS: Units with this symbol on their rules card may make assaults against units that are an extra number of tiles away equal to the numeric value listed to the side. Count through the closest route to get to the target before making a ranged assault. Features and enemy units block line of sight (except when a Flying unit is targeted or is making the assault) and empty spaces (spaces without a tile) always block line of sight. If a unit being assaulted is not capable of meeting the range requirements to the attacker, they may not roll their OFF dice for that assault.

DEPLOYMENT: In place of activating one of your units already on the map, you may choose a unit from your reserves (any of the units you didn't put on the map at the start of the game that haven't been captured by enemies) and place them adjacent to any feature on the map that you control (provided the space is unoccupied). If no such tile exists, you may not deploy a unit until one opens up.

Any player may, in place of performing a regular move action, move a piece into an occupied feature tile to return that unit to reserves. Similarly, a unit that is occupying a feature may move into that feature to return to reserves, though you then cede control of the feature by doing so.

TYPES

Listed directly beneath a unit's name are a number of “types” (Human, Elf, Robot, et cetera). These types have no effect on their own, though are referenced by certain abilities and terrain effects that may either be beneficial or detrimental to the unit.

HAZARDS

Some terrain tiles and features contain hazards. These are special effects that occur when a unit is moved into that tile. Units that are deployed into a tile with hazard effects ignore them, as do units that have that tile type as their favored terrain.

WATER: A unit moving into a Water tile must succeed at a DV 5 DEF test or be defeated immediately after doing so.

If a feature is placed in a terrain tile, the tile counts as that feature rather than the terrain type, and therefore negates any hazard effects native to the terrain type.

VICTORY CONDITIONS

A player achieves victory as soon as their opponent (or opponents) cannot activate or deploy any units. Alternately, victory is secured the moment any single player controls all features on the map.

description.text:
One day I was on my sister's couch lying down and wanted to see some videos on my smartphone. But I did not feel like holding him.
So I decided to create this project.
The softwere used for 3D sketches was FreeCAD.
To create the g.code i used the Cura softwere.
The printer is Prusa I3 and the material PLA.

For the assembly of this small project it is necessary an M3 screw of 1cm and two springs with 2cm of length and between 4 to 5cm of diameter.

ATTENTION:
It does not work for all types of mobile phones. I know it's compatible with the Samesung galaxy S6 and S7, great part of the Huawei models. If the mobile phone model has very rounded sides it is likely that it is not compatible with this design.
If the smartphone model has the flat back then it's worth just trying.

remixed_from.author: Foen1337
remixed_from.title: Pi Camera Mount for Wanhao Duplicator i3

title: Wanhao Di3 Camera Mount + 2020 Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update 3/20/17:
I've added an arm and case for the Pi Cam. Requires an M3 bolt and nut. The design I remixed from didn't state the length of the M3 bolt and I don't have a Pi Cam to test it out with. I have not printed the arm and case to test it, but as its a remix of a couple existing designs, I don't suspect there will be problems. Let me know if there are.

Update 11/21: I just uploaded a time-lapse video - https://youtu.be/3JDzyx4wJxg
Also updated the 2020 mount so that it requires 2 bolts and nuts.

This camera mount is basically an articulating arm with 2 separate frame mounts. One for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 (it mounts to the front frame) and one for a 2020 extrusion.

Mix and match as many short arms, long arms, and 90 degree arms as you want to position the camera however you want.

There is a standard 1/4" screw mount for the camera and one for the Logitech C270.

This is a mashup of several different things to get a design that works for me with my Wanhao Di3 and my Delta.

If you want to mount it to the Di3 w/ a Logitech C270... you will need to print at least:

  • 1 x frame mount
  • 1 x arm
  • 1 x top
  • 1 x C270 hinge.

If you want to use a camera with a standard 1/4" tripod screw... then add:

  • 1 x camera mount quarter inch hinge

If you want to mount onto a 2020 extrusion, then replace the frame mount with the 2020 mount.

And if you need to change the orientation of the camera... then you can insert a 90 degree arm.

author: Joseaufilho

description.text: mirele don pepa

This case is the first part of a larger project to clean up the wiring on my MendelMax.  It contains the RAMPS and an 80mm computer fan.  It has a D-Sub 37 pin connector mounted to the side that pins out every wire on the MendelMax.  There is a D-Sub mount for the frame that plugs directly into the side of the enclosure. You can mount it either outside the frame as shown, or inside if your y-axis allows it. 
This is still a work in progress.

Still a work in progress.  I will have a wiring diagram with wire lengths and routing coming soon.  
The basic goal is to wire every wire on the machine to a single D-Sub 37 pin connector mounted somewhere convenient on the frame, then wire the ramps internally to another 37-pin connector on the case.  This keeps the electronics nice and clean and self contained.  An 80mm computer fan is provided for cooling.  The case and mount can be placed anywhere on the machine that you prefer.  I'm going to put mine under the y-table.
I'll update the files in the coming days as I print the parts and begin re-wiring everything.

title: Direct Drive for Ultimaker with Default Rods

description.header: It works and it is amazing. It boosts the accuracy extremely!
description.text:
I wanted to upgrade my UM with direct drives.
Problem: You need larger rods for this.
Solution: Replace the Rod for 10mm. I printed the parts. I mount them.
I printed some parts, to make sure, it works.

1.) Make my own Version of a Rod Spacer
2.) Make my own Version of a Direct Drive
3.) Made the Thing printable without Support
4.) Printed it. Got Screws needed M3x40mm.
5.) Make the Alu plates with the threaded M3 Stopper-ALU-M3.stl
6.) Mount it all on the UM
7.) Tested
8.) Long time testing > 10h printing
9.) Added a Fan Mount to the Steppers
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193542
10.) Added a Image to the Gallery, how to assemble it.
11.) Create the instructions for this thing.
12.) Very long time testing. > 100h printing etc.

description.header: Material i used for my Direct Drive
description.text:
• 2 x CNC Coupler 5to8mm http://www.aliexpress.com/item/5x8mm-CNC-Motor-Jaw-Shaft-Coupler-5mm-To-8mm-Flexible-Coupling-OD-20x25mm-12931-01-01/663771299.html
  • 4 x Stainless steel Inbus-screw M3x40mm
  • spacers, screws and dishes are the defaults from the UM itself
  • 4x Aluminium Plates 35 x 20 x 3mm

• Drills 2.5 , 3, 10mm
  • Grinder for the alu parts
  • Tap drill M3 for the threads in the alu parts
  • Ultimaker to print the parts

• If the CNC Coupler does scratch the inside of the Direct Driver Bottom part, use a grinder, to flatten the Screw heads.
    I tighted the screws, to fix the rods. Then i released them for like 1/4 turn and then i grinded the screw heads so they do not stand out.

  • Tight all screws from the Stepper first, move the CNC coupling in the middle , so there is a space on both sides. then tight the coupling.
    Try to move the Rods by Hand, and make sure, its not grinding anywhere.

  • I suggest you clip on a fan, so the steppers will never "melt" any of you printed parts.
• If you have any questions or problems, let me know!!

comments.text: With all do respect. The image you show that state "before/after direct drive" aren't representing general print quality without direct drive. I'm referring to the blue object on the left. I use these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40041http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... to tighten the stepper belts and my circles are perfectly circular, even those of 2mm. Of course you completely eliminate the possibility of slack on the belt by driving the rods directly, but I think the stepper belt tensioner upgrade is a little easier to accomplish. However I do think it is an interesting 'redesign' of the concept to drive the printhead.

title: Firmware FlyingBear P902 Multilang Marlin 1.1.5 & Repetier v92.9

description.text:
MARLIN UPDATED TO 1.1.5:

This is a slightly modified firmware for the P902.

  • X has -9mm offset and Y has -1 (so X0 Y0 is the corner of the bed)

  • It has all the motors calibrated (X, Y, Z and Extruder)

-Acceleration and Jerk has been decreased to avoid shakes from the machine (the print time is a little slower but quality is improved) You can change these setting from the LCD menu, remember to save the setting to EEPROM so they are kept after a reboot.

NOTE: Calibrated with PLA, if you are printing with ABS please scale your objects from 100% to 100.53%

  • BABYSTEPS enabled, this helps to correct the level of X Y or Z while printing, really helpful for fist layer not sticking.

  • THERMAL RUNAWAY enabled (If any of the thermistors fails, the print stops, this prevents the printer from burning in flames because of overheating)

  • It has EEPROM enabled (You can save your own preheat defaults and many other things)

NOTE: For the calibration and preheat settings to work you must do a "Restore Failsafe" from the "Control" menu and then "Store Memory". If you don't do the Restore failsafe the calibration settings won't take effect, and if you don't do the store memory after, the new settings will be erased after reboot.

  • The CHANGE FILAMENT now works (was disabled by default) It will pause the print, lower the bed 10 mm and move the head to the lower right corner as well as making a beeping noise to let you know, just change the filament and click the knob to continue.

  • The knob direction has been changed.

  • The Z speed has been raised to 10 mm/s

  • The homing Z speed has been raised to 6 mm/s

FOR LANGUAGE CHANGE PLEASE GO TO CONFIGURATION.H AND LOOK FOR "LCD_LANGUAGE" AND CHANGE THE VALUE AS FOLLOWS (Example: LCD_LANGUAGE en):

en English
an Aragonese
bg Bulgarian
ca Catalan
cn Chinese
cz Czech
de German
el Greek
el-gr Greek (Greece)
es Spanish
eu Basque-Euskera
fi Finnish
fr French
gl Galician
hr Croatian
it Italian
kana Japanese
kana_utf8 Japanese (UTF8)
nl Dutch
pl Polish
pt Portuguese
pt-br Portuguese (Brazilian)
pt-br_utf8 Portuguese (Brazilian UTF8)
pt_utf8 Portuguese (UTF8)
ru Russian
tr Turkish
uk Ukrainian

REPETIER:

  • V 92.9
  • Configured and calibrated as Marlin

NOTE FOR MULTILANG: It only has English and Spanish enabled. If I load all the languages to the firmware it won't fit; If you want to change or load new languages here are the intructions:

  • DOWNLOAD THE FIRMWARE FROM THING
  • UNZIP
  • GO TO https://www.repetier.com/firmware/v092/
  • SELECT UPLOAD OLD CONFIGURATION
  • BROWSE THE REPETIER FOLDER YOU UNZIPPED BEFORE AND LOOK FOR CONFIGURATION.H
  • GO TO USER INTERFACE IN THE UPPER PART
  • UNDER DISPLAY LANGUAGES SELECT THE ONES YOU WANT (IF YOU EXCEED THE LANGUAGES ALLOWED YOU WILL GET A WARNING AT THE LAST PAGE)
  • GO ALL THE WAY DOWN AND CLICK NEXT STEP TWICE (UNTIL YOU GET TO THE DOWNLOAD PAGE)
  • SELECT DOWNLOAD CONFIGURATION.H AND DOWNLOAD TO REPETIER FOLDER AND REPLACE FILE.
  • UPLOAD TO PRINTER

I added a thin calibration object so you don't waste that much filament. I just print it an leave it sticked to the bed so I can measure X and Y without problems or bending, then I remove the piece and meazure Z.

You can visit my other things, almost everything is for the Flyingbear.

IF YOU FIND THIS USEFUL PLEASE AT LEAST SAY THANK YOU

comments.text:
hi, is it better for you to isolate the SSR as in this example? or is it better to connect it directly to an aluminum profile of the printer? to make sure that it is connected to ground and in such a way as to exploit the dimensions of the aluminum profile also to dissipate the heat ..
maybe it's not better to print only the upper part to make it isolated? this is absolutely not a criticism but a question to understand what may be the best solution
comments.author: edo_drum

comments.text: It does not have to be fully enclosed like this and if you want to mount it to the aluminum profile that would be even better as it would help dissipate any heat load.  However, I have been using 3 of these in this case with no heatsink on my silicone heaters for a few years now and have never had one over heat.  The case is designed so that air can flow under the SSR and out the vents.  Really the only reason that I fully enclosed it was to make sure that no contact could be made to the terminal blocks.  Don't want to mess around with live mains power.

These are three styles of generic landing gear that I created for all of my starship models. I created these in Tinkercad and then prepared them for 3D printing in Netfabb Professional. I often glue these to the display base (which I have also uploaded to Thingiverse) and then just rest the starship on the gear. This preserves the ability of the ship to be displayed "in flight".

Enjoy!
This is a simple display base I modeled in Tinkercad. Paint it asphault-blue and paint bright yellow lines on it for a great starship landing pad!

The need for this pipe is a bit convoluted! I bought a very tasty TV Stand for Currys but everything inside ran so hot the NAS drive shut down. So I had the great idea of removing the back-panel to increase the ventilation which worked a treat. Unfortunately the cabinet sunk under the weight of the TV! So I measured the existing legs and printed a couple of these to support the middle of the cabinet. Just goes to show the simplest designs can solve a problem!

This is a simple tourist camera I modeled in Tinkercad for my daughter to use on "tacky tourist day:.

Enjoy!

print_settings.Notes:: The bottom needs supports "everywhere", while the top doesn't need supports at all.

description.text:
I made this Filament spool because I want to start extruding my own filament in the near future. So I decided to make spools that i can use to store filament on.

This spool is designed for about 1 KG of filament.

This should work with any standard filament holder (yet to be confirmed).

The spool was designed in Design Spark Mechanical and I have added the original files so you may edit as you please.

This Project is a WIP so tell me if you have any problems, ideas, or suggestions.

Printer:

Anet A8 (Prusa i3 Clone)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The bottom needs supports "everywhere", while the top doesn't need supports at all.

Assembly and Instructions

Find the 2 sets of holes near the base one the "bottom" piece and push the supports out of those holes. Then take the "bottom" piece and apply adhesive around the lip designed for the "top" piece to slide onto. Then slide the "top" piece onto to "bottom" piece and then the Spool is ready for use. to start rolling filament onto the tube use heat to bend the filament at a 90 degree angle with the short side being about 1/2 an inch or 1 cm long. then insert the filament into respective hole on the spool (Smaller hole for 1.75 mm and Larger hole for 3 mm). if you want you can heat up the loose end of the filament once again and bend it to prevent it from falling out. Then you can start rolling the filament onto the spool.

Happy Extruding!

V1.1

-Changed rotation of smaller polygons from 60 to 45 degrees to improve overall aesthetics
-Added a double wall to the center of the filament holder to make it easier to use filament holders (prevents filament that you must "lock in" from interfering)

(Future Plans)

-Change to holes from polygon to a more custom shape in order to reduce filament usage and increase or maintain the same structural strength.
-Edit the 2 layer wall system to remove the covers that hide it to allow for easier insertion of filament into the holes
-make 3 more versions that can hold 1/2kg, 2kg and 3kg of filament instead of just 1kg of filament
-make 2 versions of the spool. One with the 2-layer wall system and one with only a single wall (for less filament use)
-Design a way for the filament to be held in place once the spool is fully coiled

There are numerous trimming jigs for making 300 Blackout brass from 223 cases. Most are for the mini chop saw Harbor Freight sells. I had used that chop saw for a day until it smoked and fried on me. Took it back and got the next size up in chop saws. The typical cutting jig worked, but the cut off brass ends would get jammed in the vise on the saw. I'd have to stop to clean the brass ends out every 20 cases. I decided to make a jig that will send the ends out of the way using the bigger cop saw.

Using the jig: If you line the cop saw blade up with the case holding side of the jig, this will cut off around 1.389". Then you can trim down and clean up the case to under 1.368". I could have made it cut shorter, but I wanted the ability to fine tune the cases I use, and the chop saw blade used is a very rough cut. There is not a stop that will keep the blade from cutting the jig in half. Just stop after you have cut through the brass.

I will be working on other featured for this jig. Maybe a case hold down support and a better cut end deflector and a blade stop to ensure the jig isn't cut in half. :-)

Remember to use safety gear and practice safe use of power tools.

title: Helmet Cam Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Quick demo video, cheesey, I know!!!
https://youtu.be/pFlvhZdzYMg
Support me by purchasing filament as shown:

Follow me on Instagram:
https://www.instagram.com/brian3dprints
Mount a spinning pole with a GoPro, on your helmet and get some interesting camera angles! I designed this one specifically for my helmet (Bern Macon). Safer than comparable models out there as you don't screw anything into the helmet. In the event of a crash, the 3D printed parts will break instead of your head!

Materials needed:
(x1)1/2" PVC pipe
(x1)GoPro of your choice
(x1)Handlebar mount
Counterweight (In this case I used a small can of food but typically a bolt and nut with washers does the trick)
(x3) Ball Bearing 625 2RS 5x16x5 (I used leftovers from an Openbuilds project)
(x1) Nylon Insert Hex Locknut M5
[http://openbuildspartstore.com/nylon-insert-hex-locknut/]
(x1) Low Profile Screws M5 25mm
[http://openbuildspartstore.com/low-profile-screws-m5/]
(x1) Precision Shim (Washer) - 10x5x1mm
[http://openbuildspartstore.com/precision-shim-10x5x1mm/]
(x2) M3-0.5 22mm Steel Socket Cap Screw

I recommend sourcing these parts from somewhere like your local Fastenal or other similar nuts & bolts store.

iframe src="//rcm-na.amazon-adsystem.com/e/cm?o=1&p=12&l=ur1&category=amazonvideosubs&banner=11XR3BAGVDW8V1CS1SR2&f=ifr&lc=pf4&linkID=147e88161f62c53cef1660014e6c3a2c&t=brian3dprints-20&tracking_id=brian3dprints-20" width="300" height="250" scrolling="no" marginwidth="0" frameborder="0"

Printer:

RigidBot

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

300 microns

50%

Screw the M5 screw up through the HelmetBottomMount. Place the precision spacer and then the bearings onto the screw. Tighten down with the M5 nut. Next place the PVC pipe through the HelmetPoleMount. Insert the first assembly into the HelmetPoleMount. Tighten the M3 screw into the side of the HelmetPoleMount. Add your handlebar mount and GoPro to one end of the PVC pipe and add counter weight to the other. Done.

A round hair clip.

I designed this in anticipation of receiving my 3D printer kit and putting it together, so I have not yet actually printed this. In theory, the design should work fine resized directly to whatever clip size is desired. Because it relies on slight compression in the hinge/peg and flex in the slot/tab interface to keep it together, I hypothesize that it will work better with ABS than PLA.
The initial idea was requested and drawn up on a piece of paper by a friend. I did the initial design in Inkscape to figure out sizes and shapes. For lack of a better tool flow, the spike locations were generated with Libreoffice and a little trig. The final design was constructed as parts in FreeCAD, converted to meshes, then exported to STL.
The STL looks good imported into OpenSCAD, and Slic3r had no problem generating GCode that looked good in tatlin. For some reason skeinforge crashed on the STL after a few stages with some obscure error.
UPDATE 2012-03-20: version 3. A friend with a working 3D printer printed this for me, which prompted me to 1) fix the peg, which was broken in my last update, and 2) change the diameter of the whole structure, which I had messed up by confusing radius vs diameter when I originally created it (I thought it looked funny, but wasn't sure why). This one should actually work as a hair clip!

title: Kobayashi Fidget Cube - Fat Hinge - Extra Wide Gaps

description.text:
A slight variation of my fat hinge fidget cube, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1287589
except this one has extra wide gaps between all the pieces (and the pieces are all laid out flat), so theoretically this should be easier to print. Especially if you've had problems with the other designs, with the pieces not separating.

I ran out of filament, so I actually haven't printed this one out yet. Let me know if you do!

For more information, see the original design here, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1269699

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cYAD5igMaVN

Edit: Printed! Works pretty well, but definitely more floppy. It's quite different than the original fidget cube.

comments.text: Not exactly. To do it this way, you need to find out the level of the machine itself, either across the y axis rods or the frame of the machine, then match that reading to this level, which may not always be perfect earth level.

comments.text: What we mean with "leveling the bed" is "ensure that the distance from the nozzle tip to the bed will be the same at any point over the bed. Search for dial indicators, bed leveling, auto leveling, etc. and you will find the proper tools.

author: Alex2jp

description.text: This is a less than 4" high rocket. I saw the cardboard one and thought I want to print that! I uploaded the rocket body as a single two piece print and then separately if you wanted to print in different colors. Some changes could be done: 1. Make the combined body slots deeper so the rocket will not rock when assembled. 2. The ribs could be made longer to better fit the rocket. But, it does work and is cute.

• Print all parts (Duh!)
  • Clean as required (Double Duh!)
  • Cut the slot deeper in the bottom of the non-notched rocket body profile. If you do not the rocket will rock.
  • Before final assembly put the ribs onto the notched rocket body profile first. It is easier this way.
  • Put the rocket bodies together.
  • Glue if desired.
  • Play.
    • Caution: Be warned - I showed this to a grandma I know and she immediately asked for it. :-)

comments.text: I made a rocket with an Epilog laser by making a series of circles for decks that had slots in them going almost to the center, and a series of half-profiles of the rocket to fit into them.

title: Parametric segmented track compatible with standard wooden train track

description.text:
Parametric module to create a piece of segmented track for Thomas- and Brio-compatible wooden train sets. This is similar in play value to the branded "wacky track" or "crazy track". This includes its own brim to hold the shape together while printing. The included STL file matches size and general curvature to standard "large curve" wooden tracks.

Advanced users can use parameters to customize the number of segments and track appearance, but Thingiverse Customizer can't load the external dependencies and the default values are the only ones that have been tested. To render this shape in OpenSCAD, you will need tracklib.scad and dotscad. See install instructions in each of their github repositories.

This OpenSCAD library is part of the dotscad project, an open collection of modules and Things for 3d printing. Please check there for the latest versions of this and other related files.

Printer:

Openbeam Kossel Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

Prints with its own brim, shouldn't need support. Just break off the brim and play away.

comments.text: Easily done if you just adjust the number of segments and re-render.  Or are you asking me to post an STL rendered at that size?  The main reason I didn't is that the radius of the standard "small" wooden track didn't line up very well with how the segmented version sits when there are fewer segments.

comments.text: Just an STL of a shorter version, doesn't have to be exactly half the length :)

title: Orange PI PC Case with External mounts

description.text:
Remixed from the very nice model by powermos ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1565411 )

Just worked on the bottom shell, to add four extensions on the edges, so that the case can be mounted on a plate or vertically. Top shell is the same powemos did.

This might be useful for some DIY project in which you can use the unexpensive OrangePi board for automation (e.g. I am working on a email controllable thermostat solution and need to place it on a wall beside the boiler)

Sketchup model attached for any customization need

Printer Brand:

Leapfrog

Printer:

Creatr

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

No need for supports, just make sure the flat part is on the bottom, should simply print fine.

I used Simplify 3D as a slicer: 0.2mm layer, 2000mm/min, 15% infill.
It took about 1hr and 20mins for the bottom shell to finish on my Creatr HS
I used Sketchup v8 to customize powermos' original model, then fixed filpped triangles in Simplify 3D

title: Motor enclodure and Z6 gear (for fischertechnik)

description.text:
A motor enclodure for fischertechnik.
Will require some external gear, a Z6 gear is provided for the 2mm axis of the motor.
I think, I had this motor from an old CD rom drive:
Diameter: 24,6mm
Height: approx 15mm
Axis: 2mm
Screw holes:15 mm apart (i.e. 15mm from inner sides)
The enclosure lid is tight enough to fit without glue.

Print the enclosure and the gear.
You may need to widen the holes for the motor screws.
For the power connectors, I used "Aderendhuelsen 2,5x8" from Conrad. Squeeze those into the holes, widen them a bit in order to have a tight fit and enough room for the plugs.
Solder the cables as seen in the photo. This will also keep the connectors in place.

title: Modular Drop Riffle Sluice (Small)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A modular drop riffle sluice with a wide flare (30cm/12in) for better water flow, and a V ribbed section up top so you can see when you're on the gold. Approx 15cm/6in wide riffle section.

I think it would work best with one V ribbed section, two middle sections and one end section...and the flare of course. That would make it 70cm or 28 inches long overall, with 7 drop riffles.

At a minimum I would use three riffle section as show in the attached pictures. Whether or not you use the ribbed section is up to you. If you'd prefer an extra drop riffle then just replace the v ribbed section with a drop riffle section.

Requires minimal support during print.

comments.text: Trippsy25,   Do you possibly still have the original cad file for the Drop riffle?  There is a tiny gap between the side wall and the riffles I would like to try and fix...it is printing it separate from the rest of the sluice and causing a weak breaking point in the wall.
comments.author: Prusai3Aurora

comments.text: I just made these on tinkercad so just go there and upload the file on there, insert a shape to bridge the gap and download the file. Bang done. Should take 5 minutes.
comments.author: Prusai3Aurora

comments.text: Hey Trippy, I watched your videos of you using this,  I have been messing around with the idea myself but the print times scare me away lol.  anyway what print settings did you use and how long did it take to print?
comments.author: Prusai3Aurora

comments.text: Cant remember the precise settings, but I can remember it was lower than the "Low Quality" setting on Cura. Print times, even on that, were about 10-15 hours per segment. Printing at a decent quality would take around a week of constant printing for the whole sluice I reckon. Seems daunting but I think its time well spent. Considering the saving that can be made I rather spend the time as opposed to my hard earned dollars.
comments.author: Prusai3Aurora

comments.text: Completely agree with you there, I printed 1 section with maker geeks raptor series pla and it turned out great with the exception on one side wall it printed without being combined with the rest not sure if it was my printers fault or something in the g code making the gap.  I want to print it in abs but hate that it warps just not sure how well the raptor series pla will hold up in water.  Might try making an encloser out of cardboard to try the abs print.
comments.author: Trippsy25

comments.text: Try PETG.  Best of both worlds when talking about PLA and ABS
comments.author: Prusai3Aurora

description.text:
This barn is one of two Saxon barns / byres designed for the 28mm wargaming scenery area, though of course this style will be suitable for pretty much any period through mediaeval and beyond - in fact 'til they started making barns out of metal frames. I have made two - this one for the upmarket landholder, probably those rich monks up at the monastery, and a second one for the more rustic market - same style but not so well squared timber, and with a thatched roof. And it's got a trough as well. The two will mix-and-match if you want, but I've kept them separate to avoid confusion. I've included a base but they'll free-stand just fine.
As usual, thanks to Erik and Halfdan, the two viking Gripping Beast miniatures who stick their nose in most of my piccies.

title: 30cm Leadscrew motor Mounts Prusa MK2 & Others
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I designed these so we (Prusa MK2 Owners) could purchase and install standard freely available 30cm leadscrew motors rather then having to purchase the specific Prusa MK2 32cm motors which sometimes can be pricey and a long wait to receive. At least these can get you up and running quickly and easily.

They also work for those using the I3 reprap frame however you need to use a nut and bolt to mount them.

No support but I did use some brim.

Printer:

Original Prusa MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10-30%

Notes:

A pretty universal and easy print. Infill and resolution can vary. No raft or supports needed but I did use a little brim to be on the safe side.

author: freekiland

remixed_from.author: splirus
remixed_from.title: Kossel Tech Folger 2020 - Effector/Extruder Upgrade Proximity Sensor + 2xFan Cooling

title: Folger Tech Effector and Sensor Holder Remix

description.text:
When changing to the E3D Lite6 hotend, I needed to adjust the size of the effector & sensor mount. Since the E3D lite6 hotend is shorter than the hotend supplied by folger tech, I needed to be able to move the proximity sensor further up & in order to miss the connecting rods had to shift it in 3mm also. I added the optional Fan tube for cooling that I remixed in openscad from this: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1378065 . I thought I might be able to get 2 fans on there, but was too tight a fit, so I used one of the fan connection points on the sensor mount to wire tie the hotend wires. I also did not have very good success with this cooling fan. My fan did not put out enough air & also the bracket broke. I left that in the design in case someone else wants to try it or improve on it. I might try another fan later.

The effector part has a slightly deeper arc cut in where the rod ends meet to allow more clearance for the proximity sensor. I also made the locknut holes open at the top to make it easier to assemble the rods. The access to the locknuts worked really well for me.

I have included the openscad source file & 2 STL files. The parts for the Sensor holder you can create individually in the openscad file if you want. Just set the DrawPart variable to the part you want to create or set to 1 to see the parts assembled.

I used the original STL files from the Folger Tech design as the starting point for the effector & sensor mount.

remixed_from.author: Trezhunter
remixed_from.title: Shock-Absorbing Landing Legs for F450 / Q450 style Flamewheel Xframe Quad-copter Multirotor DJI

title: Landing gear with suspension for multicopters

description.text:
This is a modified version of TREZHUNTER's creation. This slight re-arrangements of the parts allow for a higher position (camera below) and also the tip of the leg does not require to slide against the ground (in case of grass landing this tip gets stuck and the suspension doesn't work at all). Also because of the use of multiple springs, this mod allows for higher level of customization for different models and loads.

Enjoy!

Original design: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DAa98AsKnw
Remix: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j8QEC2NwjlY

looked fun - combined this with trig and squared functions

Still if you want almost no code to produce an interesting shape - here it is!!!

If you want to change the open scad code feel free - but a word of warning it takes ages to render afterwards.

PL:
Robot drukujący - zainspirowany sphere o-botem od jjrobots oraz egg-bot (open source). Zastosowano modyfikacje aby można było drukować na: piłkach do ping-ponga, jajkach, małych i dużych piłkach do 11cm średnicy, regulacja wysokości ramienia pisaka, pisak z dociskiem sprężynowym połączonym z serwer. Całość oparta na ARDUINO LEONARDO, obudowa elementy montażowe wydrukowane z PLA temp.210st.C. Wysokość warstwy 0,3mm dla dużych elementów i 0,2mm dla małych elementów. Wypełnienie 20% dla dużych i 50% dla elementów dociskowych i drobnych. Szczegółowy opis znajduje się na http://jjrobots.com/sphere-o-bot-assembly-and-user-guide/ . Projekt obudowy montażu - własny. Miłej zabawy.
EN:
Robot print - inspired by the sphere o-bot from jjrobots and egg-bot (open source). Applied modifications to be able to print on: balls ping-pong, eggs, large and small balls to 11cm in diameter, height-adjustable shoulder pen, pen with spring-loaded connected to the server. The whole is based on ARDUINO LEONARDO, housing mounting printed PLA temp.210st.C. Layer height of 0.3 mm for large items, and 0.2 mm for small items. Ratio 20% for adults and 50% of the pressing elements and small. A detailed description can be found on http://jjrobots.com/sphere-o-bot-assembly-and-user-guide/. The design of the installation - your own. Have fun.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

SPECTRUM START BASIC and PRO (2printers)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,3 and 0,2 mm

Infill:

20% and 50%

This part was inspired by the Raspberry Pi Cat Laser Toy 2.0 by Tony D. He reluctantly glued his laser mount to pan/tilt. This mount provides a snap in holder for the laser diode and the pan/tilt device.

I drilled and tapped the hole under the laser diode for a 3 mm screw. Insert a nylon screw of a length such that head is flush with bottom of mount just as the threaded end begins to touch the laser diode.

Laser Cat Toy: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FRvKtcemXkM
Laser Diode: https://www.adafruit.com/products/1054
Pan-Tilt Kit: https://www.adafruit.com/products/1967

It is a spool holder.
Please use in combination with spool stand.
Please prepare the bearing yourself.
